body:
Please reopen when you’ve added a test case for this issue.

Thanks!
Wrong fix, turns out we should add the el's **top** and not **height**. New pull request on the way...

Thanks very much for this!

I did have to reinstate the global per https://github.com/filamentgroup/fixed-sticky#using-the-polyfill-instead-of-native and switched the JS back to using tabs (as is the FilamentGroup loosely held standard) :)
Thank you! I also added a fix for when bottom > 0.
Thanks!
Thanks x2!
I'm confused. In your example, the sidebar is sticky.
Thanks for testing!
I believe this is achievable with fixed-sticky. You just need to make your sidebar table-cell and a child element inside of it sticky, right?
Thanks!

Hm?

I believe the newest Safari uses native sticky and would not apply `fixedsticky-on`.
I could not duplicate your issue with Firefox. Can you jsbin it?
Hmm. Editing the demo site and it seems to be working. I'll bang on it a little more and then get back or close this issue.
Thanks!

OK, created a reduced test case at https://github.com/robwierzbowski/fixed-sticky/tree/rw%2Bcn/abs-pos-probs

Issues are a little different than what I'm experiencing on our app, but that might have to do with me having imported the released version. These issues are against master.

Chrome: Version 31.0.1650.63
Safari: Version 7.0 (9537.71)
Firefox: 24.0 / 26.0

#### Issues with fixing an absolutely positioned el:
- Safari: `fixedsticky-on` is never applied
- Firefox and Chrome:  `fixedsticky-on` is applied, but:
  - `fixedsticky-withoutfixedfixed .fixedsticky-off, .fixed-supported .fixedsticky-off` `{position: static;}` overrides `position: absolute` applied to the original class, changing the layout when you scroll back up.
  - The dummy element is added even though the orig element was removed from the document flow.

Ha, ok. So I had been under the impression that you could apply position: sticky in CSS to non- statically positioned elements. But then I realized that's crazy talk.

My mistake. :thumbsup: :v: :ok_hand:

Sounds like you got yourself out of a

![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/361291/gifs/caruso.gif)

sticky situation

YEAHHHHHHHHHHH

I was worried for a minute, but I think I've put myself back in a 

![image](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/361291/gifs/caruso.gif)

good position.

DOUBLE YEAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHH

Are you sure you want to take this approach? It seems like you’re going to run into a lot of problems on mobile devices with overflow.

Regardless, I don’t think this is a use case we’re likely to want to support in the core library—sorry! If you’d like to discuss further please feel free to do so, but I’m going to close this ticket for now. Thanks!

Hi Zach, thanks for the answer. I am now curious regarding the problems with overflow you are mentioning, do you have any link to show?

It's a pity though because the native implementation of position: sticky; allows this use case and that's why I came here in the first place thiking that your polyfill had a bug :)
Hmm, maybe I’m misunderstanding your use case? Can you whip up a quick demo on jsbin or something so I can see what you’re referencing?

Sure: http://jsfiddle.net/g4sRY/13/

Nav and content are fixed. I need to scroll the content, not the body.

Try it in Safari, you'll see it works!

If you’re browsing `demo-control.html` that file doesn’t use the polyfill. It is named as such in the context of a Control in a science experiment.

`demo.html` should work fine. Make sure you check the DevTools to make sure the JS is loading correctly in your environment. Please reopen if you have additional questions. Thanks!
Please check https://github.com/marcosgallardo/jquery.sticky ... We are adding more documentation soon.
@dendril This doesn’t seem to address the question in the issue.
Not sure what you mean here, sticky elements are constrained to their parent containers by default. The plugin operates with that in mind.

Sorry, let me try and be a little more specific. If I have a scrollable div in the middle of my page. If a child contained in that element could be stuck to that specific element when scrolled. It appears the current implementation only works when my element and it's parent are scrolled to the top/bottom of the window.

If anyone here uses angular I just made a directive for this script
https://github.com/randallmeeker/psFixedsticky
Please reopen if needed.

Ah, so I did a bit more research on this for #16 and I don’t think we’ll be polyfilling this case.

As a workaround, use position: fixed for your NAVIGATION header and use the normal page scrolling for your address book (remove the overflow). I think this will save you some headache later on anyway.

Good luck!

See also #13.

Unfortunately, I don’t think we’ll be supporting this use case. We tend to avoid element-overflow whenever possible for the widest support on touch screens (and easiest true-to-native scrolling).

Sorry! Feel free to fork and I’d be happy to include a link in the README.
I like this. I wonder, though, if setting a width on the fixed element is necessary?

I can't tell what the dotnotation is used for (it's undocumented?). If you mean to bind both events, use a space.

Anywho. A possible solution could be replaceing .trigger('scroll.fixedsticky') with triggerHandler(...). That avoids resetting the scroll position, but should trigger the internal functions still. Let me know what you think.

Oh, huh.

The dot notation is for namespaced events. http://api.jquery.com/event.namespace/

I checked in a fix that doesn’t use trigger, can you retest (and reopen if needed)?

Thanks!
Works. Applied patch manually to local version 0.1.3

Presumably the browser is remembering the top offset when refreshing, would it be possible to detect when a page is loaded and immediately that top offset is > 0, then put back to top 0, before init'ing the sticky.

@topherauyeung @nonuby actually the code suggested here: https://github.com/filamentgroup/fixed-sticky/issues/20 seemed to fix the issue here. Tested on latest OSX Mavericks, latest Chrome, Firefox and Opera.
What browsers? I am having trouble reproducing this.
A ha, nevermind. I understand now—the sticky element has to start at the top!
Fixed by 72749f1ffc42e8d2d5c8f7eb436e7acdccea163a
`$( "#myElement" ).fixedsticky( "update" )` inside a resize handler should do it. Please reopen if that didn’t answer your question!

Hm, this seems to only apply when `top` and `bottom` are both set on the same element.
I created a test case for this: http://filamentgroup.github.io/fixed-sticky/demos/demo-top-and-bottom.html

It seems the behavior is the same in both Firefox and Chrome. Is this something you’d like to see fixed? Not sure if it’s a real world use case or not.

I am sorry but i am still having problems. 
Seems like the height of the invisible element is calculated "before the floats" of the inside elements after resize. In other words the height of the "pseudo placeholder" is the total height of all the columns not the tallest column height, after the window is resized. The result is that the sticky element "pops" when scrolling, as if something is missing when position fixed kicks in.

Also the sticky footer/bottom fails to work after window resize.

Hope this is understandable :)
Thanks!
Done!
Yay!
Do you know if any polyfills/fork of this polyfill implement this?

I have the same issue.  I have a sticky element with {top: 0}.  On Chrome, $el.css('bottom') returns 'auto', so position.bottom gets correctly set to false.  On Firefox, $el.css('bottom') return '0px', which causes position.bottom to get incorrectly set to true.

As a workaround, explicitly setting {position: static} on the sticky element fixes the problem.
Not really, no, other than we’d have to add a bit more CSS to reset `top`, `bottom`, `left`, and `right` values. I’d be in favor of changing this!
Thanks!

Do you have a link to this issue? Here's a working example with the hash jump.

http://jshawl.github.io/fixed-sticky/demos/demo.html#jump
Yeah, this is a known issue, currently listed as `Make sticky smoother on transition between sticky/static for container based` as a TODO on the readme. I like your idea! I’ll have a look.

here's a different query plugin where I'm doing that type of work already. it now does some sticky polyfilling, behind the other work it does managing display based on size of a column's content, and other special behavioral tests that one of my sites needed.

i ended up just using negative top w/ fixed positioning to scroll the element off screen. absolute/bottom would save some need to content related measurements, but for this case I was already doing them all.

https://github.com/placenamehere/stickycolumn
Alright, this should be working in the issue-28 branch. Have a look, I’ll leave it here for a bit and think over the weight/benefit of the feature.

That is a good question. My hunch is that 90% of the use cases will be vertical and not horizontal, but I’ll leave this open and if people want this they can leave a comment. Or if someone wants to code this themselves, feel free and we’ll look at merging in, I don’t think the impact will be huge.
Yes, I’d be open to adding AMD support here! It wasn’t baked in from the beginning, if that’s what you’re asking.

Yep. Just needed to know if it was supported or if I was doing something stupid.
But it would be a nice addition to support AMD as lots of people use them today :D.
Just needing that feature now and it seems barely any sticky polyfill seems to be able to do this. Would be a really useful option for us.
+1 This was exactly what I needed. I hope to see this also in the master branch.

This is true of all transitions from `position: static` to `position: fixed` on scroll. I came here hoping that this library would have found a way to circumvent this problem, but no such luck. Let me know if you discover anything and I'll do the same. [My SO question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26979089/convincing-replication-of-css-position-sticky-on-mobile)
eek - just spotted a regression bug - line 145 rolls back commit c58fbea (nOOb mistake). Apologies.
I started to merge this to have a look but some of the tests are failing. Can you patch that up?
Thanks! (I removed the width stuff)

Closing this. As of right now, Firefox and Chrome are reporting `bottom: auto` for the initial value. If overridden (as shown in the test case above), Firefox and Chrome both report the correct value, 0px.
This seems specialized enough that it will require an example. Please reopen this issue with an attached test case (or codepen, jsbin, etc). Thank you!
Thanks @jshawl! @johnstrawserjr please reopen with a test case if this is still an issue.

Hm, after looking at this a little closer, I’m going to remove it—sorry. I’m concerned about the semantics of a `refresh` method that basically does the same thing as `destroy` without reinitializing.

The test for this was also unreliable and failing sometimes inconsistently.

Keep in mind that you can use `$('#myel').fixedsticky( 'update' );` to perform a more semantic “refresh” function.

I feel like this will get fixed upstream, a la http://developer.telerik.com/featured/scroll-event-change-ios-8-big-deal/ I don’t think we’ll solve this in our plugin. Alternatively, native sticky support will also solve this.
You’re right. This assignment needs to be made before you make any calls to $.fn.fixedsticky. I added some clarity to the readme.
Thanks!

Hi Zach, Thanks for giving it a go. I'm in the process of building a bigger PR with full sticky sidebar support http://codepen.io/pixelthing/pen/wBGwVK (I just need to check for memory and destroy() compatibility) so I could either patch this one up or get the bigger one ready, depending on whether you prefer the small steps or less PRs. Cheers!

Sorry for the hassle - I've updated my fork with docs, demos and new features (that also happen to address some of the existing feature requests - although I know you're also working on them in a separate branch). As soon as I've gone through the tests and figured out what I need to do with them, I'll swap to another PR and kill this one.
Could not reproduce on Chrome 39 on Yosemite at http://filamentgroup.github.io/fixed-sticky/demos/demo.html. Please reopen if you have more details about your environment.

This is a blocking issue for most of my use cases. The code in the `issue-28` branch works fine, there's just two things I'd change:
1. Don't provide styles for `.fixedsticky-off-transition-bottom` or make the container support top and bottom padding. See also #35.
2. Don't hide the dummy for either of the transition cases.

Yeah, this took me awhile to learn back when I first started working on this polyfill.

Sticky elements are only sticky inside their parent. Instead of height: 2000px on .main use it on header.
OK, Thanks. I didn't realize this was how sticky was supposed to work. Looks like it's not going fit my needs then.
Hi. Can you cut a new version with this fix?  Really need this and would be nice to keep on official releases.  Thanks!
Ah, sure! v0.1.4 should be available now.

I hear you, sir! I’m really glad you posted your frustrations here—I’ve made some changes to the documentation—especially around the heavy restriction of sticky elements staying inside their parent containers. Will you take a look and let me know if that’s more clear? Would love your help on improving it.

As for container padding, this is currently highlighted on Issue #35.

Thanks for the quick feedback.  After I wrote this I eventually figured out how the containers thing worked, which was definitely a breakthrough!  I also realized that in order for it to work on a direct descendent of the `body` tag I had to remove `height: 100%` from my CSS.  I think it's also probably good to point out that margins aren't maintained, only paddings (I think) on the fixedsticky element.
They will be, after #35! Thank you!

Update: It looks like forcing the polyfill in all browsers is probably the best way to achieve this, as described in the readme:

`FixedSticky.tests.sticky = false;`

I would love to find out if detecting the active / inactive state of sticky positioning will ever be possible in the native implementation, since special styling based on that seems like a pretty common use case.
would be really helpfull for us, too. just wanted to let you know that ;)

When the polyfill behavior is used, the `fixedsticky-on` class means the sticky behavior is currently active on the element.

Let me know if you have additional questions!
Huh—yes, I can reproduce this.

Correct, that was noted in the issue description.  The suggestion is to consider adding a mechanism for styling when an element is sticky and sticky position has native support (i.e. when the Polyfill is not in effect).

Oh! Sorry—I misunderstood. Do you have an example of the style you’re trying to add?

Seems like the workaround here (use the polyfill everywhere) might be acceptable for now, since so few native implementations exist (and in fact, native support is diminishing).

We consider overflow to be somewhat of an anti-pattern, given spotty mobile support. Therefore, we probably won’t add this—sorry!

The readme does currently say: “This plugin does not support overflow on parent elements.”
I agree about the workaround.  Thanks for discussing!
Did a bit more testing, and found this doesn't quite work  in all scenarios. Will try to re-open when I've fixed it
Needed this in a project, so I pushed the latest stable tag to NPM.  @zachleat I'll be happy to make you an owner and remove myself from publishing whenever is convenient for you.
Hm, I think the build is failing because the QUnit grunt task requires bower modules.
The `postinstall` references a local installation of bower. Bizarre.

Hey @tbranyen,

Any chance you can make filamentgroup the owner?
Added a `before_script` to install Bower dependencies before Travis build & it seems to be back to green!
@jefflembeck all set!

guys

can’t you see that all this fighting is tearing me apart
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/361291/gifs/fightme.gif)
![](http://wil.to/_/attack.gif)
Thanks!
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/361291/gifs/fight.gif)

You may be able to extend the JavaScript using this code to keep the element in the bounds:

``` js
$('#fixedQuoteSidebar').css('width', $('#fixedQuoteSidebar').parent().width()).fixedsticky();
```

Note: You need to reassign the width whenever the browser is resized.
This would be pretty helpful for us as well..
+1 for a fix :cake:
@pixelthing as bonus I just tested your version and it seems to fix https://github.com/filamentgroup/fixed-sticky/issues/44
For me too !
@Marmeladekuchen, move your call to `$( '.fixedsticky' ).fixedsticky();` _below_ the fixed-sticky code. You're trying to call it before it exists. :smiley:
👍Can this be merged?

Thanks Paul!

I guess this proves my Javascript skills big time. ;)
:ok_hand: No problem!

I found the solution.

Its because jquery.mobile.css has multiple overflow-x:hidden; in my case I have commented the property overflow-x: hidden; of the following css rules : .ui-panel-wrapper / .ui-mobile .ui-page-active and .ui-content .
Nevermind I see this is on npm https://www.npmjs.com/package/fixed-sticky

+1

Any fix or workaround in sight?
+1 please & thanks
Ditto. I'm sad that this won't work with a sidebar in Chrome. :(
thank you
Might be a good idea. Also suggesting to the browser what will change via `will-change` might be a good idea here.

Using [`static` for sticky is a bug](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-position-3/#valdef-position-sticky). It should as per spec instead be `relative` and it caused a couple of problems in my recent testing.
I assume this is also mostly because of the usage of `position: static` while the element is not fixed on the page.
Yeah, still an issue in Safari 9.0.3

as you can see - i added support for polyfilled (fixed sticky) inside an overflow:auto container. 
https://rawgit.com/soenkekluth/sticky-state/master/examples/index.html

so the native feature becomes statefull and the polyfill supports different viewports. browser support : >= IE9 no dependencies! jank free with animationFrame

and finally: polyfill behaves exactly like the native feature...
https://rawgit.com/soenkekluth/sticky-state/master/examples/index.html
utraperformant!
see #87

there is also a react component for that: 
https://github.com/soenkekluth/react-sticky-state

there is also a react component now 
https://github.com/soenkekluth/react-sticky-state

Looks great! I’d love some of these ideas in the fixed-sticky plugin. I made an issue for one above.

I don’t think we’ll support the `overflow` feature but can you be more specific about some of the other complaints re: performance and `resize` problems? We do have resize handlers in our plugin.
Oh, and if you’re using our demo code you should at probably include some kind of attribution, yeah?

@zachleat of course i will add attribution to the demo.
when i was using fixed-sticky not long ago in a project the dimensions of the fixedsticky-dummy were not recalculated when the window resized for example. in your update method you recalculate several values like dimensions of the sticky element and the parent offsets and so on. in my module i cache these values and only recalculate them if really needed. then your not using animationFrame... and well... jquery is not really needed

you could easily use https://github.com/soenkekluth/fastscroll
I used it for https://github.com/soenkekluth/sticky-state
Thanks!
Sorry this was late. Thanks!

Ran into this same issue and tried to merge this but ran into test errors. I pushed a change that updates the dummy height correctly, so if you ever circle back to update this, please pull first. Sorry I’m so late with these merges
One small change since this PR went in, Chrome removed their impl
Thanks!

I don’t think we’ll put this into the stock plugin. It’s included easily enough in downstream CSS and I think might be a little too aggressive.

Sorry, thanks for the PR!
Still an issue in Safari 9.1 and doesn't work in Safari for iOS
You might want to try this fork: https://github.com/pixelthing/fixed-sticky

ok, got a workaround:

in https://github.com/filamentgroup/fixed-sticky/blob/master/fixedsticky.js#L100 it caches the position-object (with top/bottom true or false) as data-attribute, so it is possible to declare this data-attribute in the html:

`<div class="fixedsticky" data-fixed-sticky-position='{"top": true, "bottom":false}'>...`

If it is present, it will skip the computation of this values.
Do you mean Chrome 51? That's where I'm having the issue. Chrome 52 should support position: sticky; (http://caniuse.com/#feat=css-sticky).
I am currently on chrome 52 beta and having this issue. position:sticky seems not to be supported yet on chrome 52 (OS X)
I can see the broken behaviour in Chrome 51, 52 (Beta) and 53 (Canary), but it is still working as intended in Chrome 50 (OS X). @macrozone workaround is currently resolving the issue.
@zachleat Can this be merged into the master branch at some point? Seems to work well, or at least it did until issue #100
Not working for me too.
This does nobody any good without steps to reproduce, example code, a detailed description of the issue, etc.
I should qualify this. If the sticky element has flex: auto, then it's fine, but if no value is supplied, it seems to flicker.
Okay, after more digging, it appears the issue is actually due to the use of vh units in the element's padding.

Hi @zachleat, do you have something planned here?

Would you accept a PR here?
This would be nice.
@zachleat any idea of when we will see this merged?

This is still an issue for me. It's disappearing at the bottom of my containing element in chrome 55 on OS X. My sticky element is tall-ish (height:651px;).

@zachleat Is there a workaround I can use in the meantime? I'm happy to try and make a PR if need be.

This issue must be a joke, @soenkekluth how can you open an issue in a repo that is not yours without having contributed to it at all and saying that the **code is a mess**?

The first thing you point in the issue is **better use mine**, latter you wrote 3 more comments just talking about how **utraperformant!** its your repo and pointing to the React version of it, which is not related at all with this.

I mean im happy that you have created your own repository and you think it's better than this one, but you should learn how to respect code of other people and don't use it to SPAM them in [other](https://github.com/filamentgroup/fixed-sticky/issues/84) [issues](https://github.com/filamentgroup/fixed-sticky/issues/93). This stuff doesn't help anyone, not the maintainers, not the users and not you.

What I could notice is that Chrome doesn't support position:sticky; while Safari and Firefox does.
In Chrome it falls to position:fixed; breaking the layout when you use it as sidebar sticky.
The div class="fixedsticky-dummy" appears on Chrome's Inspector while in Safari and Firefox it doesn't.
Browsers tested:
Safari Mac 10.0.2
Firefox Mac 50.1.0
Chrome Mac 55.0.2883.95

I had that same issue. You can [force the polyfill](../#using-the-polyfill-instead-of-native), which worked for me.

`FixedSticky.tests.sticky = false;`
I had this issue as well, but couldn't trace the issue to `vh` or fix with `flex: auto`. I was able to fix by adding `backface-visibility: hidden` to the sticky element and everything within it.
It also has problems when page resizes.
FYI: Chrome 56 added support for `position: sticky` even for table elements. (https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2017/01/nic56)

Would love to see a solution to this.  Fixed-sticky elements "jump" to the top of the page too early with an implementation that's even simpler and more commonplace: asynchronously-loaded ads (for which a height is not known until the ad is loaded, which seems to happen after fixed-sticky has been initialized).
not working
I'm looking too.. currently evaluating https://github.com/wilddeer/stickyfill
